Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. UDP
d. TCP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model. It is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between hosts across network boundaries. Ethernet (b) is a data link layer (layer 2) protocol, while UDP (c) and TCP (d) are transport layer (layer 4) protocols.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. J. (2011). Computer Networks (5th Edition). Pearson.']

Question Text: Which of these is an example of something that works on the application layer (layer 5 of the five-layer TCP/IP model)?
Choices:
a. A router
b. A browser
c. UDP
d. An ethernet cable
LLM Explanation: A browser, such as Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Microsoft Edge, operates at the application layer (layer 5) of the five-layer TCP/IP model. The application layer is where user-facing software interacts with the network, allowing users to access network services. Browsers are applications that enable users to interact with web servers and access web pages.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'TCP/IP Protocol Suite, 4th Edition by Behrouz A. Forouzan']

Question Text: Which layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with cabling and connectors?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The application layer
LLM Explanation: The physical layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with the physical transmission media, including cabling and connectors. It defines the electrical and physical specifications for devices, and the relationship between a device and a physical medium. The physical layer is responsible for transmitting raw bits over a communication channel.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2013). Data Communications and Networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill.', 'Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th ed.). Pearson.']

Question Text: Which level of the TCP/IP five-layer model does a router operate on?
Choices:
a. The data link layer
b. The transport layer
c. The application layer
d. The network layer
LLM Explanation: A router operates at the network layer of the TCP/IP five-layer model. The network layer is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between different networks. Routers use IP addresses to make decisions about where to forward packets to reach their destination network.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: On which layer are Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operating?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The data link layer
LLM Explanation: Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operate on the data link layer. The data link layer is responsible for node-to-node communication and includes protocols that operate on a link between two directly connected nodes. It handles issues like physical addressing, network topology, error notification, ordered delivery of frames, and flow control. Ethernet and Wi-Fi are examples of data link layer technologies.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: Which of these allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of ethernet protocol data?
Choices:
a. A hub
b. A collision domain
c. A cable
d. A switch
LLM Explanation: A switch allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of Ethernet protocol data. Unlike a hub, which simply rebroadcasts incoming data to all connected devices, a switch intelligently directs data only to the intended recipient device by examining the Ethernet frame headers. This allows a switch to create separate collision domains for each port, improving network efficiency. A cable is just a physical connection medium, and a collision domain refers to a network segment where packet collisions can occur, which is not directly relevant to the question.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, by James Kurose and Keith Ross (Pearson)']

Question Text: What does LAN stand for?
Choices:
a. Local area network
b. Little area network
c. Large area network
d. Locally available network
LLM Explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network. It refers to a computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, office building or group of nearby buildings.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2013). Data communications and networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill.', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-lan-local-area-network.html']

Question Text: What's a router?
Choices:
a. A physical layer device that prevents crosstalk
b. A device that knows how to forward data between independent networks.
c. A more advanced version of a switch
d. A physical layer device that allows connections for many computers at once
LLM Explanation: A router is a network device that operates at the network layer (Layer 3) of the OSI model. Its primary function is to forward data packets between different networks based on the IP addresses in the packet headers. Routers use routing tables and protocols to determine the best path for forwarding packets to their destination networks. Unlike switches, which operate within a single network, routers enable communication between independent networks.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. J. (2011). Computer Networks (5th Edition). Pearson.']

Question Text: Which of these is a server?
Choices:
a. A device operating on the data link layer that connects many devices together and inspects ethernet protocol data
b. A device that forwards data between multiple networks
c. Something receiving data from something providing data
d. Something providing data to something requesting the data
LLM Explanation: A server is a device or program that provides data or services to other devices or programs, known as clients, upon request. It operates on a client-server model where the server provides resources and the client consumes those resources. Therefore, option d, 'Something providing data to something requesting the data', best describes a server.
URLs: ['https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/network-layer/what-is-a-server/', 'https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/server']

Question Text: What kind of wiring is in cables that communicate in voltage changes that are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros?
Choices:
a. Fiber
b. Aluminum
c. Gold
d. Copper
LLM Explanation: Copper wiring is used in cables that communicate in voltage changes, which are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros. Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is commonly used in network cables like Ethernet. The voltage changes in the copper wire represent the binary data being transmitted.
URLs: ['https://www.webopedia.com/definitions/copper-cable/', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/copper-cable']

Question Text: What modulation type is used for computer networks?
Choices:
a. RJ45
b. Simplex communication
c. Line coding
d. Line crimping
LLM Explanation: Line coding is the modulation technique used in computer networks to convert digital data into a format suitable for transmission over a communication channel. It involves representing the digital signal with an analog waveform that can be transmitted over the network medium. Line coding helps ensure reliable transmission by providing synchronization and facilitating clock recovery.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'Data and Computer Communications, 10th Edition by William Stallings']

Question Text: What is the difference between full duplex and half duplex?
Choices:
a. Half duplex occurs when hubs are in use; full duplex occurs when switches are in use.
b. Full duplex allows communications in two directions at the same time; half duplex means that only one side can communicate at a time.
c. Full duplex is a form of simplex communications.
d. Full duplex is slower than half duplex.
LLM Explanation: Full duplex allows communication in both directions simultaneously, meaning both devices can transmit and receive data at the same time. In contrast, half duplex only allows communication in one direction at a time - when one device is transmitting, the other can only receive, and vice versa. The duplex mode is independent of the type of network device (hub or switch) being used. Full duplex is not a form of simplex (one-way) communication, and it is generally faster than half duplex as it allows for more efficient use of the communication channel.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs, by Wendell Odom', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition, Chapter 5: The Link Layer and LANs, by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: The ____________ consists of devices and is responsible for sending signals between devices.
Choices:
a. network layer
b. data link layer
c. physical layer
d. modulation
LLM Explanation: The physical layer is responsible for the actual transmission of raw data bits over the network communications media. It consists of the hardware devices and physical cabling required to send the signals between devices. The physical layer defines the means of transmitting raw bits rather than logical data packets over a physical link connecting network nodes.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: What is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices?
Choices:
a. Power Cable
b. Twisted Pair Cable
c. VGA Cable
d. SATA Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted pair cable is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices, especially in Ethernet networks. It consists of pairs of copper wires twisted together to reduce electromagnetic interference and crosstalk. Twisted pair cables are widely used due to their low cost, flexibility, and ability to carry high-speed data over reasonable distances.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press, 2019)', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross (Pearson, 2016)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-an-ethernet-cable.html']

Question Text: Which of the following are category types of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP).
b. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP).
c. Shielded Twisted Pair (STP).
d. USB Cable
LLM Explanation: Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP) are the two main categories of twisted pair Ethernet cables. UTP cables do not have any shielding, while STP cables have a metallic shielding to protect against electromagnetic interference. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP) is not a standard category, and USB cables are not twisted pair Ethernet cables.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'Network+ Guide to Networks by Jill West, Tamara Dean, Jean Andrews']
SM - Description: Even if folded twisted is not a standard category, it is still a category of ethernet cables

Question Text: How many octets are there in a MAC address?
LLM Explanation: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique identifier assigned to a network interface controller (NIC) for use as a network address in communications within a network segment. A MAC address is 48 bits (6 bytes) in length and is typically represented as 12 hexadecimal digits grouped in pairs, separated by colons or hyphens. Since each pair represents one byte (octet), there are 6 octets in a standard MAC address.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13715-160.html']

Question Text: What address is used for Ethernet broadcasts?
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet broadcast address is FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF. This is a special MAC address used to send Ethernet frames to all devices on a LAN segment. When a frame is sent to this address, all devices on that segment will receive and process it.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: What is a cyclical redundancy check?
Choices:
a. A way for two computers to synchronize their clocks.
b. The actual data being transported by an Ethernet frame.
c. A technique that allows for multiple logical LANs to operate on the same equipment.
d. A mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact.
LLM Explanation: A cyclical redundancy check (CRC) is a mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact during transmission. It is an error-detecting code commonly used in digital networks and storage devices to detect accidental changes to raw data. The sending device calculates a CRC value based on the data being sent and appends it to the message. The receiving device then performs the same calculation on the received data and compares the calculated CRC value with the one received. If they match, it indicates the data likely arrived without errors.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclic_redundancy_check', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/cyclic-redundancy-checking']

Question Text: Which of the following are ways for transmitting data at the Ethernet level? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Multicast
b. Duplex
c. Broadcast
d. Unicast
LLM Explanation: At the Ethernet level, data can be transmitted in three ways: a) Multicast, where data is sent to a group of destination addresses simultaneously;c) Broadcast, where data is sent to all devices on the network; and d) Unicast, where data is sent to a single destination address.Duplex (b) refers to the mode of communication (half-duplex or full-duplex) and is not a method for transmitting data at the Ethernet level.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: Which of the following are parts of an Ethernet frame? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Data payload
c. EtherType field
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: An Ethernet frame consists of several parts, including:b. Data payload - This field contains the actual data being transmitted, which can be up to 1500 bytes.  c. EtherType field - A two-byte field used to indicate which protocol is encapsulated in the payload (e.g., IPv4, IPv6, ARP).d. Preamble - A 7-byte field with alternating 1s and 0s used for synchronization between the sending and receiving devices.'Broadcast' is not a specific part of the Ethernet frame structure.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/8021q/17056-741-4.html']
